author: Arsene Lupin III
subject: "Lupin in English FAQ" commentary.
body:
> 1978 Mystery of Mamo/Secret of  Mamo/Lupin vs the
> Clone/Lupin vs Kuron/Lupin vs the Immortal Man 
> (Lupin nei Fukusei Ningen/Mamoo no Ichihen ) 
> - originally titled "Lupin III" when released in
> Japan, the later titles were added to avoid
> confusion with subsequent films.  

Pretty much accurate here, but there's only one person
who I know that calls it "Lupin vs. Kuron," and that's
Valerie, a former list regular. A Neko fansub of
"Secret Files" called it "Lupin vs. Kuron," without
relaizing "Kuron" was katakana for the English word
"Clone." I have seen Japanese web pages call the film
"Lupin tei Fukusei-Ningen <Kuron>," or in English:
"Lupin vs. The Immortal Men <Clones>." 
So the film, in Japan, has 2 titles:
"Lupin vs. The Immortal Men/Lupin vs. The Clones"
or
"Lupin the Third."
In English, 2 titles:
(UK Dub): "The Secret of Mamo"
(US Dub): "The Mystery of Mamo"

I have no idea where the title "Mamo's First Copy"
(Mamoh no Ichihen" came into play. I would go ahead
and leave it in though, just for the 'halibut.'

> SUB Any *english* fansubbed versions of this exist?
> (I know of a Finnish sub)
> INP Lupin Gang Anime (on hold)

I think all the fansubbers just decided to wait it out
and see if anyone besides Streamline would touch it.
Or they simply couldn't get a steady translator to do
it (LGA falls into that category). If you want an
accurate translation of the film, I would suggest
viewing the TMS dub from a few years back, and ignore
the weird name changes.
 
> 1979 The Castle of Cagliostro (Cariosutoro no shiro)
> SUB/DUB Manga Ent. VHS/DVD (Region 1), sub script by
> Neil Nadelman
> SUB/DUB Buena Vista Home Ent. DVD (Region 2), uses
> Streamline dub and Carl Macek's english script for
> subtitles (dubtitle)
> DUB Streamline Ent. VHS (OOP), Toho dual language LD
> (OOP) 
> SUB many fansubs exist from public scripts, most are
> now redundant to the commercial Manga sub.

Ah, but there were 2 *theatrical* English subs of
Cagliostro. One was released in limited quantity by
Streamline Pictures in 1991. It was very accurate,
besides Lupin being called "Wolf." 
There was also another one made years before
(presumably by TMS Japan), using an original sub
script. The names were changed (except Lupin's, I
would guess) much like they were for the TMS dub of
Mamo... e.x.: "Detective Scott" instead of "Inspector
Zenigata." The Streamline theatrical sub was likely
based on the translation used in this release.

> 1982 Lupin VIII/Arsene and Company/Arsene et cie 
> - pilot film of a series (Japan and France
> coproduction, and possibly DIC in Canada?) aborted
> due to copyright issues between Leblanc estate and
> TMS.
> INP ??? Pilot exists without vocal track which may
> have never been recorded. 

Yeah I read an interview that said a bit about Lupin
the Eighth (thanks Ryu!). It was a French
Co-production with Japan (it's been done before), and
DiC had a hand in it too. I think DiC was more
directly connected to the French end of the deal than
Japan.
On a side note, there were actually 6 episodes
completed before they cancelled the series due to the
LeBlanc name (it was no going to be public domain
until 1991 and the "Lupin VIII" series was being made
in 1980-1981), but only the premiere is floating
around....

> 1984 Lupin III Part 3 (TV Series, 50 episodes)
> SUB Lupin Gang Anime ep 2, 6, 9, 17
> 
> 1985 Legend of Gold Babylon/Golden Legend of Babylon
> (Babiron no Ogon Densetzu)
> SUB AnimEigo VHS/LD as "Rupan III"

The way it's written, it should be "Golden Legend of
Babylon" or even simply "Gold Legend of Babylon."
AnimEigo rearranged the words and added an "of," and
in doing so, altered its literal meaning a tiny bit:
"Legend of the Gold of Babylon."

> 1987 The Fuma Conspiracy/Plot of the Fuma Clan
> (Fuuma Ichizoku no Imboo)
> SUB/DUB AnimEigo VHS/LD as "Rupan III"
> SUB ???

The AnimEigo LD was not available dubbed. So I would
write it:
SUB/DUB AnimEigo VHS as "Rupan III"
SUB Animeigo LD as "Rupan III"

There were fansubs of this made, but I don't know any
subber names. It was the source of the English title
"Plot of the Fuma Clan," a more accurate translation
than "The Fuma Conspiracy," though I admit
"conspiracy" is a pretty cool word. You can find a
subtitle script for it online.

> 1989 Goodbye Lady Liberty/Bye Bye Liberty Crisis -
> Begin Emergency! (Bai Bai Ribatii - Kiki Ippatsu!)
> DUB Manga Ent UK VHS (PAL TV format only)
> SUB Studio Banzai
> SUB Nippon Golden Network (Hawaiian TV/KHML)/J.N.
> Productions

It's either "Bye Bye Liberty-Begin Emergency!" or "Bye
Bye Liberty Crisis." Not a combination of the 2. ;-)

> 1994 Mighty Sword that Cuts Steel/Zentesu Sword is
> on Fire (Moeyo Zantetsuken)
> SUB Odyssey Anime (v1)
> SUB S. Baldric productions (bootleg?)

The reason I called them bootleggers on my site is
because Fansubs.net called them bootleggers. I can't
say personally because I never dealt directly with
them.
 
> 1995 Pursuit of Harimao's Treasure (Harimao no Hiho
> wo Oe)
> SUB Odyssey Anime (v4)
> INP Lupin Gang Anime - timing

It's "Harimao no Zaiho wo Oe!" And it literally means,
"After Harimao's Treasure!" But I like the way most
people write it, "Pursuit of." A commercial release
would probably change it a more literal translation
(though AnimEigo, a commercial company,  seems to like
toying with titles just a little).

> 1996 Dead or Alive (Deedo oa Araibu)
> SUB Lupin Gang Anime
> INP Odyssey Anime

The title screen of this film is actually written in
English, and so are all the video covers. I've only
seen it written as "Deedo oa Araibu" on the covers of
the Japanese film-to-manga adaptations, so I mentioned
it on my site anyway.
 
> 1996 Legend of Twlight Gemini/Secret of Twilight
> Gemini (Towairaito Jemini no Himitsu)
> SUB Odyssey Anime (v2)
> SUB Lupin Gang Anime
> SUB Neko Creations (defunct)
> - Neko's sub scripts are publically available

"Legend of Twilight Gemini" is the official English
title, but a translation of the Japanese name would
make it "Secret of Twilight Gemini."

> 1997 In Memory of Walther P-38/Island of Assassins
> (Warusaa P-38)
> SUB Lupin Gang Anime
> INP Odyssey Anime

"Island of Assassins" was NTV's English distro name
for the film. It's also called "I.o.A." in Spanish
versions. Much like they call "Kutabare! Nostradamus,"
"Farewell to Nostradamus," they don't take huge effort
in keeping the titles true to their source names.

> 1998 Memories of Blaze - Tokyo Crisis (Honoo no
> Kioku - Tokyo Crisis)
> SUB Lupin Gang Anime
> INP Odyssey Anime
> 
> 1999 Fujiko's Unlucky Days - Da Capo of Love  (Ai no
> Da Capo - Fujiko's Unlucky Days)
> SUB Odyssey Anime (v1)
> SUB Don Quixote
> INP Lupin Gang Anime

"Don Quixote" is one of many false names for a
bootlegger that exists in New York City. His group has
done the first 2 Pokemon films (under the name
"Pikachu Project," imitating the Japanese group that
worked on the film's creation), as well as a so-so
copy of "Da Capo of Love." 
If you visit Anime VCD (I forget the URL, but it's
hosted by Angelfire.com), they sell lots of VCD
versions of "Don Quixote's" bootlegs at premium prices
($12+ a pop). Many of these titles are Lupin III
films, which are possibly (and likely) VCD conversions
of Lupin Gang Anime subs. 
The font used for "Da Capo of Love" is the same that
LGA has used for years, perhaps to "blend in" amidst
the other VCD pirates.

> 2000 1$ Money Wars
> INP Odyssey Anime

The next special, Lupin the Third: Alcatraz
Connection, should be coming out on NTV's Friday
RoadShow this July, and I hope Odyssey will simply
jump at the opportunity to make it.

Just a little FYI for the folks and Rob to help
improve the FAQ.
